### ğŸ“˜ Overview  
This report analyzes how **subway ridership volume** and **transit-related crime** correlate across NYCâ€™s transit system (2015â€“2025).  
This report makes use of **API-acquired open data**, monthly aggregation, robust data cleaning, correlation analysis, as well as visualizations in order to analyze time-varying crimeâ€“ridership dynamics.
:::

### ğŸš‡ Specific Question (SQ): Does Subway Ridership Volume Correlate with Transit Crime?

âœ” My SQ examines how both **monthly subway ridership** and **transit-related crime** move together  
âœ” I use **NYPD Complaint Data** (filtered by subway incidents) as well as **MTA Monthly Ridership** from the years **2015â€“2025**  
âœ” I evaluate if higher ridership corresponds to **higher crime counts** at a system-wide level  
âœ” I also separates my analysis into **overall**, **pre-2022**, and **post-2022** time frames to accommodate for any COVID-era disruptions  
âœ” Finally, I incorporate **correlation measures**, **indexed trends**, as well as **crimes per million riders** to capture both risk and volume performance  

â¡ The overarching goal is to assess whether transit crime correlates with ridership volume, focusing on how this relationship may have changed in more recent years.

### ğŸ“ Step 2: Creating Project Data Directory

### ğŸš¨ Step 3.1: Download Transit-Related NYPD Complaint Data (2015â€“2025)

âœ” Obtains **only complaints related to subway** from NYC Open Data API  
âœ” Applies a **date filter from 2015â€“2025** to avoid downloading irrelevant rows  
âœ” Uses a **SELECT statement** to keep essential fields  
âœ” Expands API limits, ensuring full and filtered dataset is returned  
âœ” Saves cleaned CSV (locally) for quicker re-runs and reproducibility   

```{r}
# =========================================================
# 3.1 NYPD COMPLAINT DATA
# Only transit-related complaints, only 2015â€“2025
# =========================================================

complaints_req <- request("https://data.cityofnewyork.us/resource/qgea-i56i.csv") |>
  req_url_query(
    "$select" = "cmplnt_num,cmplnt_fr_dt,juris_desc,prem_typ_desc,boro_nm,ofns_desc,law_cat_cd",
    "$where"  = "cmplnt_fr_dt between '2015-01-01T00:00:00' and '2025-12-31T23:59:59' AND (juris_desc = 'N.Y. TRANSIT POLICE' OR prem_typ_desc = 'TRANSIT - NYC SUBWAY')",
    "$limit"  = 500000
  )

complaints_path <- file.path("data", "courseproject", "complaints_transit_filtered.csv")

complaints_req |>
  req_progress() |>
  req_perform(path = complaints_path)

complaint_df <- readr::read_csv(
  complaints_path,
  show_col_types = FALSE
)
```

âœ” Obtains **system-wide monthly ridership** for subways in NYC (2008â€“present)  
âœ” Makes use of NY State Open Data archival API for stable downloading  
âœ” Saves dataset to `data/courseproject/` for project structure that is consistent

### ğŸš¨ Step 5: Building System-Wide Monthly Transit Crime Counts

âœ” **Only subway-related incidents** are included after filtering NYPD complaint records   
âœ” Takes each complaint as **single crime event** for aggregation on system-wide level   
âœ” Converts complaint dates into **monthly units**, enabling time-aligned comparison with ridership
âœ” Helps to ensures that only unique complaint numbers are counted in order to avoid duplication  
âœ” Outputs crime totals (monthly) needed to evaluate the SQ  

â¡ Creates the core dataset in order to analyze how transit crime levels fluctuate relative to subway ridership.
```{r}
# 5. Building Monthly Transit Crime Counts (System-Wide)
#SQ: Does subway ridership volume correlate with the number of crimes?
#Here we treat transit-related complaints as "crimes".
#ridership <- readr::read_csv(path_ridership, show_col_types = FALSE)
```
### ğŸš¨ Filtering & Structuring Transit-Related Complaint Records

âœ” Cleans column names for consistency across both datasets  
âœ” Keeps only the complaints by **N.Y. Transit Police** or that occur in **NYC Subway premises**
âœ” Converts raw complaint date into standard `Date` format  
âœ” Converts dates to **monthly periods** using `floor_date()` to correlate with monthly ridership

â¡ This process helps to isolate transit incidents, preparing them for correlation analysis on the monthly-level.

```{r}

complaints_transit <- complaint_df |>
clean_names() |>

filter(
juris_desc == "N.Y. TRANSIT POLICE" |
prem_typ_desc == "TRANSIT - NYC SUBWAY"
) |>
mutate(
date = as.Date(cmplnt_fr_dt),
month = floor_date(date, "month")
)
```
### ğŸ“… Restricting Complaints to 2015â€“2025 Analysis Window

âœ” This step removes complaints so that only incidents between **2015 and 2025** are included  
âœ” Removes incomplete or outdated records that falls outside the range for analysis

â¡ This helps ensure that the dataset is focused and pertains to the SQ.
```{r}
# =========================================================
# ğŸ”— 4. restricting to our 2015â€“2025 window
# =========================================================
complaints_transit <- complaints_transit |>
filter(between(date, start_date, end_date))
```
### ğŸ” Ensuring Unique Complaints & Building Monthly Crime Totals

âœ” Uses `distinct()` in order to keep **only one record per complaint number**. This helps to prevent any accidental double-counting  
âœ” Also groups the cleaned records by **month**, keeping in line with the structure of the ridership dataset  
âœ” Counts total amount of **transit-related complaints** during each month  
âœ” Produces a reliable and clean `felony_count` metric for analysis of crime 

```{r}
# =========================================================
# ğŸ“Š 5. creating monthly transit crime counts
# =========================================================
complaints_transit <- complaints_transit |>
group_by(month) |>
summarise(
felony_count = n(), # total transit complaints per month
.groups = "drop"
)

summary(complaints_transit$felony_count)
head(complaints_transit)
```
### ğŸš‡ Building Monthly System-Wide Subway Ridership

âœ” This step standardizes names of columns for consistency  
âœ” Detects **date column** and **total ridership column**  
âœ” Using `floor_date()`, converts date values into periods on the monthly level   
âœ” Helps ensure the ridership field is properly listed as a numeric value
âœ” Filters the dataset to the **2015â€“2025** analysis window for our scope of study  
âœ” Ridership at the **monthly level** is aggregated, producing a `subways_total` metric  

â¡ This step creates a monthly ridership series essential in comparing against monthly crime counts.
```{r}
# =========================================================
# ğŸ“ˆ 6. Building System Wide Monthly Subway Ridership
# =========================================================

monthly_ridership_df <- monthly_ridership_df |>
clean_names()

# ---- A) Trying to detect date and subway ridership columns ----
date_col_r <- names(monthly_ridership_df)[
str_detect(names(monthly_ridership_df),
regex("date|month|period", ignore_case = TRUE))
][1]

sub_col_r <- names(monthly_ridership_df)[
str_detect(names(monthly_ridership_df),
regex("subway|subways.*total|ridership", ignore_case = TRUE))
]

to_numeric <- function(x) {
if (is.numeric(x)) as.numeric(x) else readr::parse_number(as.character(x))
}

ridership_month <- monthly_ridership_df |>
mutate(
month = floor_date(
parse_date_time(!!sym(date_col_r),
orders = c("ymd", "mdy", "my")),
"month"
),
subways_total = to_numeric(.data[[sub_col_r[1]]])
) |>
filter(
between(month, start_date, end_date),
!is.na(subways_total)
) |>
group_by(month) |>
summarise(
subways_total = sum(subways_total, na.rm = TRUE),
.groups = "drop"
)
```
### ğŸ”— Step 7: Merging Crime and Ridership Data & Creating a Normalized Metric

âœ” This combines monthly ridership totals with monthly crime counts through the use of a `left_join()`  
âœ” Takes out months where any dataset is missing values to keep analytical integrity  
âœ” Outputs **crimes per million riders**, a measure (normalized) which accounts for changes in ridership volume
âœ” Lets the analysis differentiate amongst changes in *crime totals* as well as changes in *crime risk per rider*  
âœ” Outputs a `merged` dataset that is used for visualization and correlation analysis  

â¡ The sanity checks in the code below (`summary()` and `head()`) confirm that the dataset that is merged works as expected prior to further analysis.
```{r}
# 7. Merging Crime and Ridership & creating normalized metric
merged <- ridership_month |>
left_join(complaints_transit, by = "month") |>
filter(!is.na(felony_count), !is.na(subways_total)) |>
mutate(
crimes_per_million = 1e6 * felony_count / subways_total
)
# =========================================================
# sanity check
# =========================================================
summary(merged$crimes_per_million)
head(merged)
```
### ğŸ§  Interpretation: Crime per Million Riders

1. Transit crime rates varied from **approximately 4 to 38 crimes per million riders** throughout the period of study.  
2. The years **2015â€“2017** showcase **higher per-capita crime**. This can be attributed to the fact that ridership was at peak levels whereas crime counts seemed to stay relatively steady.  
3. Following **2018**, per-million crime rates are seen to fall while ridership remains high; crime totals do not increase at the same pace.  
4. The **COVID-19 period** disrupts both ridership and crime. It creates sharp swings in per-capita values which influence later correlation patterns.  

â¡ Overall, it can be seen that rider risk decreases prior to COVID, becomes unpredictable during the pandemic, and then stabilizes again once ridership begins recovering.

```{r}

p_trend <- ggplot(merged, aes(month, felony_count)) +
geom_line(alpha = 0.5) +
geom_smooth(se = FALSE, linewidth = 1.1) +
labs(
title = "Monthly Transit Crime Trend (2015â€“2025)",
subtitle = "Raw counts with LOESS smoothing to highlight long-run pattern",
x = "Month",
y = "Transit-Related Complaints (count)"
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 13)

p_trend
```
### ğŸ§  Interpretation: Smoothed Monthly Crime Trend

- Monthly transit crime showcases **substantial short-term noise**, but the line (LOESS) shows us a much smoother underlying pattern.  
- Crime levels seem to be **relatively high pre-2018**, trend downward slightly, and finally rest around a lower plateau.
- During the **COVID period**, crime counts fall, but not as sharply as ridership, creating an apparent dip followed by a rebound.  
- Following 2022, we can see that the smoothed trend indicates **gradually rising crime counts**. This is consistent with our correlation and risk metrics.  

```{r}
#8. Correlation Analysis for SQ
# "Does subway ridership volume correlate with the number of crimes?"

cor_overall <- cor(merged$felony_count, merged$subways_total, use = "complete.obs")

cor_pre2022 <- merged |>
filter(year(month) < 2022) |>
summarise(cor = cor(felony_count, subways_total, use = "complete.obs")) |>
pull(cor)

cor_post2022 <- merged |>
filter(year(month) >= 2022) |>
summarise(cor = cor(felony_count, subways_total, use = "complete.obs")) |>
pull(cor)

cor_table <- tibble(
Period = c("All Months (2015â€“2025)", "Pre-2022", "2022+"),
Correlation = c(cor_overall, cor_pre2022, cor_post2022)
)

print(cor_table)


cor_table_gt <- cor_table |>
mutate(
Correlation = round(Correlation, 3)
) |>
gt() |>
tab_header(
title = "Correlation Between Ridership and Transit Crime by Period"
)

cor_table_gt
```

### ğŸ§  Interpretation: Correlation Between Ridership and Transit Crime

1. The **overall correlation is not too strong (0.29)**; this indicates that ridership and crime share a weak but notable correlation.  
2. **Pre-2022**, the correlation is at the weakest (**0.19**); this suggests that crime levels did not scale in a meaningful manner with changes in ridership.  
3. **Post-2022**, the correlation strengthens substantially and is at its highest point in our study (**0.54**); this indicates a more clear relationship amongst ridership volume and crime counts.  
   - As ridership recovers, **crime counts rise proportionally**.  
   - Transit crime appears **more sensitive to crowding and rider volume** in recent years.  

â¡ These results show us that the relationship between ridership and crime is **time-dependent**. The relationship grows stronger in the post-COVID recovery era.

### ğŸ§  Final Interpretation for SQ: Ridershipâ€“Crime Relationship (2015â€“2025)

- Transit crime and subway ridership show a **modest overall positive correlation** across 2015â€“2025 (**r â‰ˆ 0.29**).  
- This relationship is **not stable over time**:  
  - **Pre-2022:** Correlation is quite weak, indicating crime levels didn't scale strongly with ridership.  
  - **Post-2022:** Correlation increases significantly (**r â‰ˆ 0.54**); this suggests crime counts now rise more consistently with recovery in ridership.  
- Normalized crime measures (**crimes per million riders**) add more insight:  
  - Per-rider risk **fell sharply in 2018â€“2019**, whereas ridership peaked and crime counts remained predictable and stable.  
  - Post-COVID levels of risk **rise again** as crime grows at a quicker rate than ridership.  

â¡ Overall, more recent years demonstrate a higher correlation between rider volume and crime levels, while normalized metrics highlight that **per-rider risk has increased** despite crime totals not rising dramatically.

::: {.callout-important}
### ğŸŸ£ Key Takeaway: Ridershipâ€“Crime Dynamics Have Shifted Post-COVID  
- The ridershipâ€“crime correlation strengthened substantially after 2022.  
- Rider risk (crimes per million riders) has increased in recent years, even without dramatic increases in total crime.  
- System-level crime trends must be interpreted relative to underlying ridership volume, not in isolation.  
:::

### âš ï¸ Limitations

- NYPD complaint data reflects **reported incidents**. This may under-represent actual crime levels and can vary with the nature of reporting.  
- Ridership data is based on **turnstile entries/exits**. This may include noise from repeat taps or non-trip-related swipes. Additionally, there may be riders who didn't tap or swipe their cards.  
- COVID-era months disrupt standard time-series assumptions. This makes trends more harder to estimate.
- Categories of crimes are **aggregated across offense types**; certain categories may show different dynamics when compared to the system-wide pattern.

- Improve the analysis to either the **station or line level** in order to identify high-risk routes as well as localized hotspots.  
- Incorporate **lagged relationships** (such as ARIMA and VAR) in order to assess if changes in ridership predict future crime.  
- Add **covariates** such as police deployment or service changes.
- Explore **predictive models** in order to predict months that are high-risk for riders or periods where MTA should focus more on resource allocation and staffing.
